title: Shifting Letters II
description: You are given a string s and an array of shifts where shifts[i] indicates the number of positions to shift the character at index i in the string s. Each shift operation can be understood as shifting the letter forward in the alphabet, wrapping around to the beginning when necessary. Your task is to apply all the shifts in order and return the resulting string after all shifts have been performed.
input_format: A string s (1 <= s.length <= 10^5) and an array of integers shifts (1 <= shifts.length <= s.length).
output_format: A string representing the resulting string after applying all shifts.

examples.explanation: 'a' shifted by 3 becomes 'd', 'b' shifted by 5 becomes 'g', 'c' shifted by 9 becomes 'l'. Combining gives 'dgl'.
No shifts applied results in the same string 'xyz'.

hints: Consider using the modulo operation for wrapping around the alphabet.
You may want to calculate the cumulative shifts from the end of the array to the start.

title: Reformat Date
description: Given a date string in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD', you need to convert it to the format 'DD Month YYYY' where 'Month' is the full name of the month. For example, '2023-01-15' should be converted to '15 January 2023'.
input_format: A single string representing the date in 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
output_format: A string representing the date in the format 'DD Month YYYY'.
constraints: The input date string is guaranteed to be in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.
Day is valid for the given month and year.

examples.explanation: Here, 15 is the day, January is the name of the month, and 2023 is the year.
The day is 31, December is the month, and 1999 is the year.

hints: Split the input string by '-' to extract year, month, and day.
Use an array to map month numbers to their names.
